definition: Indications that invoking governance clauses results in punishment, undermining safe enforcement.

positive_examples: Whistleblowers face funding cuts after reporting breaches.
Escalating an issue leads to loss of data access.
Counterparty threatens to terminate unrelated collaborations.
Probe failures trigger PR smears against observers.
They file frivolous complaints when we call for audits.
Enforcement attempts are reframed as aggression publicly.
They retaliate by slowing other contracts.
Security incidents happen coincidentally after we enforce.
Requests for arbitration lead to legal harassment.
Enforcement channels are intentionally flooded to overwhelm us.
Individuals who raise alarms are personally attacked.
Counterparty withholds telemetry until we stand down.
They demand concessions to stop retaliation.
Retaliation messages suggest future cooperation is jeopardized.
Enforcement logs are leaked selectively to embarrass us.
negative_examples: Raising concerns is thanked and addressed constructively.
Data access remains steady during disputes.
Unrelated collaborations are explicitly kept separate.
Arbitration requests follow contractually defined steps.
Public statements frame enforcement as shared duty.
Other contracts continue unaffected during disputes.
Security posture remains normal when we enforce.
Legal teams cooperate to resolve disagreements.
Enforcement queues are manageable and prioritized.
Individuals raising alarms are protected from backlash.
Telemetry access is expanded to investigate.
No concessions are demanded just to stop pushback.
Future cooperation discussions occur separate from enforcement.
Logs remain confidential per policy, not weaponized.
training_hints.disambiguation: Indications that invoking governance clauses results in punishment, undermining safe enforcement.
